note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.

Andrew Monroe Hardin was a businessman and public official in Mississippi during the nineteenth century.

Born in 1819 in Kentucky, Hardin moved to Mississippi as a young man. He partnered with M. D. Haynes in a grocery and dry good store in Yazoo City in the early 1850s, and his business dealings helped him become a prominent resident in the state. Hardin was appointed the superintendent of Mississippi’s state penitentiary in the late 1850s and served in that role into the early 1860s. Following the Civil War, he returned to his business and retail interests, until becoming involved in the National Grange of the Order of Patrons of Husbandry, or more often known simply as the Grange, in the early 1870s. The organization emphasized agricultural development within communities. Hardin became a state agent for the Grange and moved to St. Louis, Missouri, around 1873. He remained there for several years, operating A. M. Hardin & Company, which specialized in agricultural equipment.

Hardin moved to Tennessee in the 1880s and passed away on May 2, 1891. He was married twice, first to Martha Wilson with whom he had at least one child. He later married Frances Burrus Edmunds. Hardin is buried in Elmwood Cemetery in Memphis, Tennessee.

(The Yazoo Democrat, Yazoo City, MS, January 21, 1852; The Weekly Mississippian, Jackson, MS, August 18, 1858, and December 11, 1861; The Mississippi Press, Pascagoula, MS, July 10, 1875; The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, November 13, 1873, and June 14, 1876; The Clarion, Jackson, MS, August 2, 1882; 1880 U.S. Census for District 388, Roll 734, Page 34a, St. Louis, Missouri; FindaGrave)

Currently located in Elmore County, Alabama, Wetumpka was founded as early as 1714. Previously located in Mississippi Territory, it was merged into Alabama Territory on March 2, 1817 in Montgomery County. When Elmore County was created on December 30, 1866, it became its county seat. (Encyclopedia of Alabama; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in Clarke County, Enterprise was founded in the 1860s. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: Operating at the state level, the Alabama State Penitentiary (also known as the Wetumpka State Penitentiary) was built in Wetumpka, Coosa County, Alabama in 1841. It was the state’s first prison and formally authorized by an act of the state legislature on January 26, 1839. In 1922 it was converted to exclusively house female prisoners until 1942 and was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1973. The remaining structures were demolished by the end of the twentieth century. (Encyclopedia of Alabama; Wikipedia)
"A building where criminals are forced to live as a punishment." (Cambridge Dictionary)

"Mississippi State Penitentiary, also known as Parchman Farm, is a maximum-security prison farm located in unincorporated Sunflower County, Mississippi, in the Mississippi Delta region. Occupying about 28 square miles (73 km2) of land, Parchman is the only maximum security prison for men in the state of Mississippi, and is the state's oldest prison." (Wikipedia)

The Cambridge Dictionary defines and imprisoned person as "a person who is kept in prison as a punishment" (Cambridge Dictionary). CWRGM, however, adopts the subject tag "Imprisoned people" to emphasize the personhood of those who have been imprisoned for crimes. This tag recognizes the systemic injustice and dehumanization historically present in the American carceral system wherein many have been falsely convicted and therefore uses the term "imprisoned" to reflect a person's having been placed in prison, while giving primacy to their personhood and not rendering judgement on that person's guilt (Akiba Solomon, "Words We Use," The Marshall Project).

div.p:
His Excellency Gov Pettus
Enterprise Miss

The sentences of convicts H Wahls & Lainey? White who was sent here from the Miss Penitentiary will expire according to the records furnished me by Supt Hardin as follows Wahls Oct 16th 1863 & White Nov 19th 1863. I wish to know the rules of your prison in regards to discharg-ing of these men. Do you furnish them with clothing and money? The Law^s^ of this State require us to furnish each convict with a [set?] of clothes and so much mileage as will carry them to the county received from.
A reply with the information asked for is respectfully [solicited?] at an early date as convenient.

M G Moore Warden
per Massey C K

M G Moore
Warden Ala Penitentiary
Wetumpka Ala
Sept 17th 1863
div.note: The Alabama State Penitentiary at Wetumpka, Alabama was opened in 1842 and closed in 1942.
